trisentis
Class Trisentis

java.lang.Object
  game.Game
      trisentis.Trisentis

public class Trisentis
extends Game

A Trisentis game is played on a boolean matrix which is specified by the number of columns and the number of rows. A click on one field turns all the neighbored fields, but not the field itself. To put some solutions together it is of interest to examine the border of the applied solutions, wherefore this class provides some methods to see it.

Author:
Irene Thesing

Constructor Detail

Trisentis

public Trisentis(int r,
                 int c)
Creates a new Trisentis game with the given row and column number.

Parameters:
r - number of rows. It must be greater than zero.
c - number of columns. It must be greater than zero.

Trisentis

public Trisentis(BooleanMatrix configuration)
Creates a new Trisentis game with the given state.

Parameters:
configuration - the state for the new Trisentis game.
Method Detail

isTrisentis

public static boolean isTrisentis()
Returns whether the game is a Trisentis game or a sigma-game on a rectangular grid, i.e. whether diagonal neighboured fields are counted as neighbored.

Returns:
whether the game is a Trisentis game or a sigma-game on a rectangular grid.

setTrisentis

public static void setTrisentis(boolean isTrisentis)
Sets whether the game is a Trisentis game or a sigma-game on a rectangular grid.

Parameters:
isTrisentis - whether a field in the middle has eight neighbors (Trisentis) or four (grid game).

getTriSolutions

public java.util.LinkedList<BooleanMatrix> getTriSolutions()
Calculates some solutions of the Trisentis game as a list of matrices, this representation is characteristic for Trisentis games and not possible for most other sigma-games.

Returns:
list of matrices, which are solutions of the Trisentis game.

getTriKernel

public java.util.List<BooleanMatrix> getTriKernel()
Calculates the base of the kernel of the Trisentis game as a list of matrices, this representation is characteristic for Trisentis games and not possible for most other sigma-games.

Returns:
list of matrices, which form a base of the kernel of the Trisentis game.

getSymTriKernel

public java.util.List<boolean[]> getSymTriKernel()
Calculates all symmetric kernel elements of the Trisentis game, this symmetric condition is meant in the first component. It is used that the first column determines the kernel element totally.

Returns:
a list of the symmetric kernel elements.

getSymTriKernelWithOne

public java.util.List<boolean[]> getSymTriKernelWithOne()
Calculates all symmetric kernel elements of the Trisentis game, this symmetric condition is meant in the first component. It is used that the first column determines the kernel element totally. Additionally, the middle element in the first column must be one. It makes sense only for odd values of #rows.

Returns:
a list of the symmetric kernel elements.

Description copied from class: Game

public int getCols()
Returns the number of columns of the game board.

Returns:

getRows

public int getRows()
Returns the number of rows of the game board.

Returns:
number of rows of the Trisentis game.

applySolWithBorder

public BooleanMatrix applySolWithBorder(BooleanMatrix solution)
Applies a solution to the zero state of the Trisentis game and returns a matrix which also includes an additional border and the corresponding values on it. It is helpful to examine whether we can put two solutions together.

Parameters:
solution - solution which shall be applied on the zero matrix (the basic game).
Returns:
a matrix which contains also a border (the only interesting thing if it is really a solution or kernel element).

applyAllSolsWithBorder

public java.util.LinkedList<BooleanMatrix> applyAllSolsWithBorder(java.util.List<BooleanMatrix> solutions)
Applies a list of solutions to the zero state of the Trisentis game and returns a list of matrices which also include an additional border and the corresponding values on it. It is helpful to examine whether we can put two solutions together.

Parameters:
solutions - solutions which shall be applied on the zero matrix (the basic game).
Returns:
a list of matrices which contains also a border (the only interesting thing).

applySolWithBorder2

public boolean[] applySolWithBorder2(boolean[] configuration)
Look at #applySolWithBorder, here only the arguments are taken as boolean arrays.

Parameters:
configuration -
Returns:
applies the configuration on the matrix with border.
